alarm.tip1: Amazon OpenSearch Service provides a set of
alarm.tip3: , Centralized Logging with OpenSearch can help customers to create the alarms automatically, and sent notification to your email (or SMS) via SNS.

monitoring.intro: This tab provides key metrics of each components within the log ingestion pipeline, making it easy for you to monitor the end-to-end log ingestion status. Please note, enabling monitoring will incur additional cost, please refer to the following link for cost estimation.

apacheLogFormat.name: Apache Log Format
apacheLogFormat.tip1: Apache HTTP Server capture detailed information about errors and request in log files. You can find the log format configuration in Apache HTTP Server configuration file, such as the
apacheLogFormat.tip2: file. The log format directive starts with

apacheLogParsing.name: Sample log parsing
apacheLogParsing.tip1: Please provide your apache log in Apache log file such as

creationMethod.name: Creation method
creationMethod.tip1: When import OpenSearch domains, you need to specify the networking configuration associated with the Log Processing Layer. The solution will automatically place Lambda (or other compute resource) in this layer. The Log Processing Layer must have access to the OpenSearch domain.
creationMethod.tip21: The solution will detect if there is a need to create a
creationMethod.tip23: . If needed, the solution will automatically create a VPC Peering Connection, update route table, and update the security group of OpenSearch domain.
creationMethod.tip3: Manually specify the Log Processing Layer networking information. You may need to create VPC Peering Connection, update route table and security group of OpenSearch domain.

ingestionCreationMethod.name: Log enabling
ingestionCreationMethod.tip1: Solution can automatically detect the log location, or you can specify the log location manually.
ingestionCreationMethod.tip2: The solution will automatically detect the log location of the selected AWS service. If needed, it will enable the service log and save to a centralized log bucket.
ingestionCreationMethod.tip3: Manually input the AWS service source and its log location. The solution will read logs from the location you specified.

instanceGroupCreationMethod.name: Instance Group Creation
instanceGroupCreationMethod.tip1: Create a new instance group, or choose an existing Instance Group created before.

logConfigPath.name: Log Path
logConfigPath.tip1: Specify the log file locations. If you have multiple locations, please write all the locations and split using ' , '. e.g.

eks.title: For EKS Log, for Sidecar and DamonSet, refer to the following instructions for configuration:
eks.dtip1: For nginx as an example, when Amazon Linux2 is selected as the image of the node, if the user deploys the same application under the same EKS Cluster and uses the Namespace to distinguish different environments, it is recommended to use the following log path
eks.dtip2Title: The format of log path is:
eks.dtip2: The <namespace> is the corresponding Namespace that distinguishes different environments, <application_name> is the name of the deployed application, <container_name> is the name of deployed container. The names of application and container are defined in the Yaml file. This is different from deploying nginx on EC2, where log names are often used under EC2. For access.log, the log name is defined in nginx.conf. When creating a configuration file in Solution, pay attention to the path location.
eks.stip1: That is, attach a dedicated log collection container to the Pod, and use emptyDir to share the log directory to allow the Fluent Bit container to read the data. Fluent Bit containers share storage, network and other resources with application containers. The volume defined in Solution is named app-log. For example: log path
eks.stip2: ,The corresponding deployed emptyDir shared volume is named app-log, refer to the following figure:

logLifecycle.name: Log lifecycle
logLifecycle.tip2: into the OpenSearch domain. The life cycle will periodically move your indices in OpenSearch to save cost.

logProcessing.name: Log Processing
logProcessing.tip1: The solution will provision Lambda (or other compute resource) to process logs using these networking configurations. You can specify the log processing networking layer when import OpenSearch domains.
logProcessing.tip2: The log processing layer has access to the OpenSearch domain.

logProcessingNetwork.name: Log processing network
logProcessingNetwork.tip1: When import OpenSearch domains, you need to specify the networking configuration associated with the Log Processing Layer. The solution will automatically place Lambda (or other compute resource) in this layer. The Log Processing Layer must have access to the OpenSearch domain.
logProcessingNetwork.tip21: By default, The solution will output error logs to Amazon S3. Please guarantee the log processing layer has network access to Amazon S3. You can do it by place the log processing layer in public subnets, use
logProcessingNetwork.tip31: Many AWS services output service logs to
logProcessingNetwork.tip33: . If you use Solution to ingest service logs. Please guarantee the log processing layer has network access to CloudWatch Logs.
logProcessingNetwork.tip4: Application logs are sent to Kinesis Data Streams in Solution. Please guarantee the log processing layer has networking access to Kinesis Data Streams.

nginxLogFormat.name: Nginx Log Format
nginxLogFormat.tip1: Nginx capture detailed information about errors and request in log files. You can find the log format configuration in Nginx configuration file, such as the
nginxLogFormat.alert1: Note: Nginx type log configuration does not support Nginx configuration in JSON format. If your Nginx configuration is in JSON format, please select the log type as JSON.

nginxLogParsing.name: Sample log parsing
nginxLogParsing.tip1: Please provide your nginx log in Nginx log file such as

regExLogFormat.name: RegEx Log Format
regExLogFormat.tip1: Solution uses custom Ruby Regular Expression to parse logs. It supports both single-line log format and multiple input format. Write the regular expression in
regExLogFormat.tip2: to validate first and input the value here.
regExLogFormat.link2: Rubular: A Rudy-based regular expression editor

sampleDashboard.name: Sample dashboard
sampleDashboard.tip1: The solution will insert a pre-configured dashboard into the OpenSearch domain if
sampleDashboard.tip2: being selected. The dashboard name will be consistent with your index name.

s3FileType.name: File Type
s3FileType.tips: You can choose a specific file type for logs stored in Amazon S3. Gzip only supports the compression of a single file.

eksPattern.name: Collection Mode
eksPattern.tip1: ensures that all (or some) Nodes run a copy of a Pod. As nodes are added to the cluster, Pods are added to them.
eksPattern.tip2: is a separate container that runs alongside an application container in a Kubernetes pod.

eksIamRole.name: IAM Role ARN
eksIamRole.tip1: When importing an EKS cluster, we automatically create an EKS IAM role for use in EKS delivery streams.

configTimeFormat.name: Time format
configTimeFormat.tip1: Solution supports all time formats provided by the
configTimeFormat.tip2: . That is, log time strings that can be formatted by the strftime function can be parsed and used by Solution.

configFilter.name: Filter
configFilter.tips1: Take the Apache Json format log as an example, the log content is as follows:
configFilter.tips2_1: Only retain requests whose method is POST, GET, POST, DELETE
configFilter.tips2_2: Filter out requests starting with /user/ and requests with paths /login and /logout
configFilter.tips2_3: Only retain logs whose level is error and warn

configFilter.filterLink: Select or exclude records per patterns

proxyInstance.name: Proxy Instance Type/Number
proxyInstance.tips: This recommendation table is base on page refresh time and average query delay, please feel free to create proxy and test base on your own use cases.

s3PrefixFilter.name: Prefix filter
s3PrefixFilter.desc: Here are some sample for you to set prefix filter:
s3PrefixFilter.li1: If the files to be ingested are all in the log/ folder, you can specify the prefix as log/
s3PrefixFilter.li2: If you want to only ingest file with log as file extension, you can specify the prefix as log/*.log

pipelineAlarm.name: Pipeline Alarms
pipelineAlarm.desc: Pipeline alarms will be triggered if any critical metric cross the threshold, which will send notifications to a SNS topic. Those alarms are created based on the best practices for log pipeline monitoring and troubleshooting, you can custom those alarms or create new alarms in CloudWatch
